column5: To remember 'bon', think of how Scottish people refer to something attractive or positive as 'bonny'./'bon' is a part of many other French words and phrases which you may already be familiar with, such as 'bon appétit' and 'bonjour'. Don't worry if you don't know these yet - you'll unlock them soon!
What do you write every day? A journal!/'jour' will appear as part of many other vocab items so make sure to remember this one.
If someone shows you mercy%' you should thank them for it.
Imagine you are complimenting Robin Hood on his beautiful bow. Or perhaps you find the man himself quite 'beau' ;)
People can't help but comment on how you do things. You think to yourself%' 'come on%' leave me be!'
English words with the prefix 'homo-' share the same origins as the French word 'homme'. This means you can think of 'homosapien'%' and be reminded of the French!

Luckily for you%' English words like 'feminine' make this one a lot easier to remember./In some situations it can also mean 'wife'%' but for now we will concentrate on its more common use to mean 'woman'.
Who says 'yes'? We say 'yes'!
column8: oui ou non/mais oui/oui et non

column5: I don't think we need to help you remember this one%' just watch out for the second n as it's subtly pronounced
column8: oui ou non/oui et non/moi non plus

column5: The way this word is pronounced is like the 'mwah%' mwah' sound French people make when they greet each other with a kiss. Think about how when someone meets you (me)%' they have to 'moi%' moi' you (me).

This one is a bit of a false friend, there is a different word that is used for train stations which you'll see later, so you'll have to remember that 'station' refers to underground train stations and bus stops.
si' is most commonly used to mean 'if'%' let's 'see' if you can remember that one. It has a couple of other uses but we'll stick with the basics for now.

Since the French language has fewer words in total than English%' words often have more than one meaning. Here it can mean the obvious (often the plural 'toilettes' is used)%' a 'wash' - think of how you use toiletries when washing - or even 'outfit'.

The French word for 'hand' shares its origins with the English words 'manicure' and 'manicle' among others%' which are not-coincidentally terms related to hands. So if you already know those you're golden.
column8: maintenant/avoir la main verte/coup de main/à la main

column5: There are all sorts of English words which share the same etymology as the French word 'pied'%' and helpfully they all relate to feet - 'pedals'%' 'pedicure'%' 'pedestrian'%' etc. All you have to do is remember that the French spelling is a little different.
I'm sure you don't need us to help with this one.
This one is pronounced similarly to 'easy' in English%' so it's 'ici' to remember where you are - you're 'ici'!

When the Angles came to Britain in the 5th century AD%' they founded kingdoms in England along with the Saxons. The French word for 'English'%' (both the language and the people) is a derivative of the name of these Germanic people. This is where we get terms like 'Anglican' (relating to the church of England)%' and 'anglophone' (English-speaking)!

Once again this refers to both the French language and the French people. This time it's the Franks who left their linguistic mark on Europe when they formed 'Francia'%' and the prefix has stuck around.
Emergencies are certainly a matter of 'urgency'!
Only one letter difference between the French and English terms here%' note that there's no accent on the 'u'%' that would make it a different word which you'll learn shortly
column8: oui ou non/être ou ne pas être

column5: When adjectives follow a noun they need to 'agree' with the noun by changing gender. In this case%' the masculine 'bon' becomes 'bonne' in the feminine

The feminine version of 'beau' differs from the masculine a little more than usual. You should have no trouble remembering this one though as beautiful characters in stories are (by design) sometimes called Belle.

The French and English are similar enough that you should be able to remember this one. If you're having trouble you could think of someone making /the/ char%' but bear in mind that it is pronounced more like 'tay'
A handy cognate for you! When talking about a pet in French you would also refer to it as an 'animal'. The plural is a little trickier to remember so you'll come across that later on.
The word 'fraternity' meaning 'brotherhood' shares its origins with the French word 'frère'%' which should make this one a little easier to remember.

As was the case for 'frère'%' a bit of etymology will help you here - 'sorrority' meaning 'sisterhood' shares its origins with the French 'sœur'. The 'o' and 'e' at the start of the word are combined into a single character (œ) so watch out when spelling this one.
You pronounce this word a little like the English word 'core'%' and you can think of your heart as the core of your body. Again%' watch for the special 'œ' character when spelling this one.
column8: coup de cœur/cœur du problème/être au cœur de

column5: A slightly more difficult one to remember for you now - if you can remember that the French starts with a 'v'%' like the English word 'vehicle'%' then it'll be a bit easier. It's a common word so don't worry if you struggle to remember it at first%' you'll be exposed to it a lot in everyday written and spoken French.
column8: accident de voiture/voiture de police/voiture d'occasion

column5: What other fruit begins with 'pom' in English? Handily it's another round%' red fruit - the pomegranate! Use your excellent knowledge of red fruit to help you learn French.
Tantalisingly close to being a cognate%' just remember that bananas belong to 'Anne'%' and not 'Anna' in France. It has some interesting other meanings in French too.
Handily%' the French word for 'you' rhymes with the English. Bear in mind that this is the more polite form%' and it is used when addressing groups of people rather than individuals.
There's not much to help you remember this one%' but perhaps you could think of it as YOU talking 'to I'. You use 'toi' instead of 'vous' when referring to a single person in an informal setting.
How many uses does a combi have? Can you combine them? The word is derived from the words 'comme' and 'bien' which you will be shown later on.
This one is pronounced 'con'%' so you can think how criminals (cons) have to do time.
Pronounced 'key'%' think about who holds the key to French-learning success: it's you of course!
Think about how maths is easy with 'a vec'tor. You'll also see this word a lot in everyday French so you'll have no problem remembering it.
Shakespeare would be less famous without 'son'nets.
This one is pronounced almost identically to 'je'%' which you should have come across already. Therefore you could think of the game 'I-spy' to help remember the word 'jeu'.
column8: jeu vidéo/jeu d'enfant/jeu de mots/jeu de cartes

column5: When you realise that you pronounce 'bébé' as 'bay-bay'%' suddenly this one becomes nice and easy to remember.
If one thing is like another%' it has a lot in 'common'

Luckily the word for male posession is the same as an English word for a young male. French posessives are a little strange however%' as they refer to the noun rather than the subject. I recommend looking in a French grammar book for more details on posessives so you can confidently use them.

As mentioned previously%' French posessives aren't related to the subject - therefore the masculine and feminine form ('son' and 'sa') can be used when a male or female subject is talking. It sounds complicated but it just takes a bit of getting used to.

You'll see this word everywhere as it can mean a few very useful words. Sometimes the final 'e' is missed off and replaced with an apostrophe%' if followed by a vowel%' but don't be fooled - it's still the same word!
Only two letters to remember for this one%' I think you can manage without one of my silly mnemonics this time around!
If you've ever read or seen Elle magazine in the shops you'll know that it's marketed mainly to women%' which is handy when trying to remember the word for 'she'.
It rhymes%' and isn't too far from the English%' so I think you've got this one.
How do you get your deliveries? By 'par'cel of course.
English words like 'surreal' and 'surpass' use the suffix 'sur-' to mean 'on' or 'over', which should help you remember the French.
What're you doing under there Sue? Sue is forever getting under things - classic Sue!
Just add a cheeky 't' and you're good to go.

Pronounced more like the English word 'show'%' you'll have to imagine yourself getting hot while watching a show - perhaps it's a cooking show you're watching and you can't stand the heat of the kitchen.
The French starts with 'fr'%' and so does the English word 'freezing'! Just be mindful of the tricky pronunciation.
